wikipedia_page.main: Vice-Admiral Sir Edward Michael Conolly Abel Smith,  (3 December 1899 – 3 December 1985) was a Royal Navy officer who served during the First and Second World Wars.

response: *Vice Admiral Sir Conolly Abel Smith, 28 April 1954 – 30 January 1958

Biter was an . These carriers were converted American type C3 merchant ships. Their design was based on the U.S. Navy′s  (AVG); to differentiate between the two classes, the Royal Navy added the prefix "B" (BAVG). HMS Biter (BAVG3) was built by the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, originally named the Rio-Parana; she was laid down on 28 December 1939, launched on 18 December 1940 and delivered on 4 September 1941.Cocker (2008), p.78. She was converted to an escort carrier in the Atlantic Basin Iron Works at Brooklyn New York and commissioned into the Royal Navy on 6 May 1942, under the command of Captain Conolly Abel Smith.Poolman (1972), p.51.

She was converted to an escort aircraft carrier in the Atlantic Basin Iron Works at Brooklyn New York and commissioned into the Royal Navy on 6 May 1942, under the command of Captain Conolly Abel Smith.Poolman (1972), p.51.

Through his daughter Ethel, he was a grandfather of five, three boys and two girls, including Lady Katherine Ethel Carnegie (b. 1892), who married Maj. Arthur Rivers Bosanquet, eldest son and heir of Richard Arthur Bosanquet; Charles Alexander Carnegie, 11th Earl of Southesk (1893–1992), who married Princess Maud (a granddaughter of King Edward VII); Commander Hon. Alexander Bannerman Carnegie (b. 1894), who his cousin Susan Ottilia de Rodakowski-Rivers and, after her death, Cynthia Averil Gurney; Lady Mary Elizabeth Carnegie (1899–1996), who married Vice-Admiral Conolly Abel Smith; and Major Hon. James Duthac Carnegie (1910–1996), who married Claudia Katharine Angela Blackburn, a daughter of Lord of Session Robert Blackburn, Lord Blackburn, and granddaughter of Claude Bowes-Lyon, 13th Earl of Strathmore and Kinghorne.
